docs.lead_paragraph: Thais Faria sank into a leather love seat, relaxing under the ministrations first of a masseuse, then a manicurist and finally a hairdresser-cum-makeup artist. Not 24 hours after her daughter was born via cesarean, Faria was being pampered at an upscale Rio de Janeiro maternity clinic.

headline.main: Luxury Birthing Clinics Spur Cesarean 'Epidemic' in Brazil
headline.print_headline: Luxury Birthing Clinics Spur Cesarean 'Epidemic' in Brazil

docs.lead_paragraph: Female workers in California will get new tools to challenge gender-based wage gaps under legislation signed into law Tuesday that supporters say offers the strongest equal-pay protection in the nation.

headline.main: California Governor Signs Law Targeting Gender Wage Gap
headline.print_headline: California Governor Signs Law Targeting Gender Wage Gap

docs.snippet: Female workers in California will get new tools to challenge gender-based wage gaps under legislation signed into law Tuesday that supporters say offers the strongest equal-pay protection in the nation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jennifer Berry, accused of throwing her newborn from a seventh-floor Bronx apartment, was considered soft-spoken by her peers and had worked for a number of social service agencies.

headline.main: A ‘Sweet and Shy’ Woman, Now Accused of Killing Her Newborn
headline.print_headline: A Woman Called ‘Sweet and Shy,’ Now Accused of Killing Her Newborn

docs.abstract: Baffled acquaintances describe Jennifer Berry, who stands accused of killing her newborn baby by throwing it from window of apartment building in Bronx, as sweet and shy; case has prompted officials to reexamine 2008 death of Berry's infant son, which was at time attributed to infant death syndrome.
docs.snippet: Jennifer Berry, accused of throwing her newborn from a seventh-floor Bronx apartment, was considered soft-spoken by her peers and had worked for a number of social service agencies.

byline.contributor: Barbara Liston contributed reporting from Altamonte Springs, Fla., and Rick Rojas and Eli Rosenberg from New York. Susan C. Beachy and Doris Burke contributed research.
byline.original: By KIM BARKER and NATE SCHWEBER

docs.lead_paragraph: Staff at Sports Direct International Plc, afraid they would be fired for taking sick leave, made more than 80 calls to ambulances from the British company's headquarters over a two-year period, the BBC reported on Monday.

headline.main: Sports Direct Staff Made 80 Calls for Ambulances-BBC
headline.print_headline: Sports Direct Staff Made 80 Calls for Ambulances-BBC

docs.snippet: Staff at Sports Direct International Plc, afraid they would be fired for taking sick leave, made more than 80 calls to ambulances from the British company's headquarters over a two-year period, the BBC reported on Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: A girl abducted from her kindergarten classroom and sexually tortured during a bizarre overnight ordeal faced her kidnapper in court Monday and asked a judge to stop her from harming others.

headline.main: Kindergarten Kidnapper Tells Girl,' I'm Not a Monster'
headline.print_headline: Kindergarten Kidnapper Tells Girl,' I'm Not a Monster'

docs.lead_paragraph: An investigation by the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) has revealed that more than 80 calls were made to ambulances by Sports Direct employees at its headquarters in Derbyshire for "life-threatening illnesses".

headline.main: For Muslim-Americans, Baby Aidan or Baby Muhammad?

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Wajahat Ali debates benefits and detractors of naming American child born to Islamic family, such as his own, with name that sounds Muslim.
